example.p: Suppose a student answers 20 true/false questions completely at random. Use a normal approximation to estimate the probability of getting no more than 8 correct. body.p: Unfortunately, the approximated probability, .1867, is quite a bit different from the actual probability, .2517. However, this example constitutes something of a "worst-case scenario" according to the usual criteria for use of a normal approximation.

Probabilities for a binomial random variable X with n and p may be approximated by those for a normal random variable having the same mean and standard deviation as long as the sample size n is large enough relative to the proportions of successes and failures, p and 1 - p. example.p: May we use a normal approximation for a binomial X with n = 20 and p = .5? In this case, np = 20(.5) = 10 and n(1 - p) = 20(1 - .5) = 10. The criteria are just barely satisfied, and so we should not expect the approximation to be especially good.

body.p: The purpose of the next activity is to give you practice at deciding whether the normal approximation is appropriate for a given binomial random variable. You'll get to practice checking the rule of thumb ( n p ≥ 1 0 and n ( 1 - p ) ≥ 1 0 ) , but also get a visual sense of when the normal approximation is appropriate.
